Reaction pathway in vapor-phase synthesis of pyrazinyl compounds from glycerol and 1,2-propanediamine over ZnO-based catalysts Xue Li Chenghua Xu ⁎ Chuanqi Liu Na Zhang Junjie You Qiang Wu Air Environmental Modeling and Pollution Controlling Key Laboratory of Sichuan Higher Education Institutes, Chengdu University of Information Technology, Chengdu 610225, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 28 85966011; fax: +86 28 85966089. Graphical abstract Highlights ► ZnO-based catalysts provide weak Lewis acid–strong Brønsted base pairs. ► Base sites favors glycerol activation through dehydrogenation. ► Acid sites catalyze glycerol dehydration and activate 1,2-propanediamine (PDA). ► 5- or 6-hydroxymethyl-2-methylpyrazine is from dehydrogenized glycerol and PDA. ► 2,5- or 2,6-dimethylpyrazine can be directly from dehydrated glycerol and PDA. ZnO-based catalysts on Al2O3 as support are prepared and modified with different metal elements through impregnation, and first applied in synthesis of pyrazinyl compounds from glycerol and 1,2-propanediamine (PDA) in the present work. The results indicate that the produced pyrazinyl compounds mainly include 6-hydroxymethyl-2-methylpyrazine (6-HMP), 5-hydroxymethyl-2-methylpyrazine (5-HMP), 2,6-dimethylpyrazine (2,6-DMP) and 2,5-dimethylpyrazine (2,5-DMP). Characterization results show that ZnO species in catalysts provide acid–base pairs (Zn2+–O2−), catalysts modified by Ce, Ca, Mn and Mo exhibit spillover phenomenon of hydrogen. According to the effect of Zn amount and modification on the physicochemical and catalytic property of ZnO-based catalysts, the cyclization pathway of glycerol with PDA is proposed. The formation of 2,6- and 2,5-DMP is thought to directly take place over acid sites through glycerol dehydration and further cyclization with the activated PDA, also through hydrodehydration of 6- and 5-HMP, respectively. 6- and 5-HMP are mainly produced by the interaction of activated PDA molecules on acidic sites with dihydroxypropanal or dihydroxyacetone from glycerol dehydrogenation on basic sites. Keywords ZnO/Al2O3 Catalytic cyclization Glycerol Pyrazinyl compounds 1 Introduction Fuel and energy crisis forces us to seek alternate fuels for future, and the biodiesel as a kind of renewable and clean energy has recently attracted more and more attention. However, biodiesel manufacturing from transesterification of non-edible oils will produce a large quantity of by-product glycerol (GL). Therefore, the reasonable utilization or disposal of GL is very important for the sustainable development of the future biodiesel industry. As reported, GL can be converted by hydrogenation to 1,2- or 1,3-propanediol [1,2], reformed by steam to H2 or synthesis gas [3,4], catalytically dehydrated to acrolein [5], and synthesized to N-heterocyclic compounds with a high industrial importance such as alkylquinolines [6], alkyl indoles [7] or pyrazinyl compounds [8,9]. Pyrazinyl compounds such as pyrazine and alkyl-substituted pyrazines are widely used as intermediates for perfumes, medicines and agricultural chemicals. As one example, 2-methylpyrazine (2-MP), which is known as a key intermediate for pyrazineamide, an effective antitubercular drug, has been prepared in the commercial scale by propyleneglycol (PG) catalytic cyclization with ethylenediamine (EDA) [10–12]. Recently, it has been found that GL can also be used as raw material providing two OH groups to interact with EDA to 2-MP through cyclization to form the intermediate 2-hydroxymethyl pyrazine, which is easily converted to 2-MP through hydrodehydration of CH2OH group with the produced H2 as described in Scheme 1 [8,9]. As well known, 1,2-propanediamine (PDA) also has two NH2 groups. Therefore, it should be possible that GL interacts with PDA to produce 6- or 5-hydroxymethyl-2-methylpyrazine (6-HMP or 5-HMP), and they will also be converted to corresponding dimethylpyrazines such as 2,6- or 2,5-dimethylpyrazine (2,6-DMP or 2,5-DMP), respectively. The proposed procedure is described as Scheme 2 . As well known, these four substituted pyrazines are also a series of important drug intermediates and perfume compounds used in food, etc. The successful application in GL cycilzation with PDA to value-added pyrazinyl compounds will be helpful to exploiting new ways for GL utilization. Therefore, the present work investigates the synthesis of pyrazinyl compounds by GL vapor-phase catalytic cyclization with PDA in fixed-bed system for the first time. As reported, ZnO-based catalysts exhibit an excellent catalytic property in PG cyclization with EDA to 2-MP [10–15]. Therefore, Sarkari et al. [8] use Zn–Cr mixed oxides as catalyst to catalyze GL cyclization with EDA, and find that they also exhibit a high catalytic activity on the synthesis of 2-MP. However, the detailed function of active species in catalysts is not mentioned, although a possible cyclization pathway has been given in this literature. As far as PG cyclization with EDA to 2-MP is concerned, some researchers [10,13,15] thought that two OH groups of PG are first adsorbed on Lewis acid sites, the activated PG interacts with EDA to 2-methylpiperazine which can be dehydrogenated to 2-MP. This proposed reaction pathway mainly bases on the fact that the formation of intermediate 2-methylpiperazine is found during cyclization. However, diamines exhibit a strong basic property due to the presence of lone-pair electrons in NH2 groups, it should be more easily adsorbed on acidic sites than glycols. Park et al. [12] found that the single GL reactant can form acetone and hydroxyacetone through dehydration and dehydrogenation over catalysts. Moreover, the conversion of GL to dihydroxypropanal or dihydroxyacetone has been observed by several authors [16–18]. Therefore, it should be worthy to consider whether the formation of pyrazinyl compounds is through the interaction of the activated diamines with these intermediates containing carbonyl groups. Of course, PDA cyclization with GL should be more complex than EDA cyclization with GL or PG, because it possibly produces four main pyrazinyl compounds according to the proposed-above process. Therefore, the present work investigates PDA cyclization with GL on ZnO-based catalysts on Al2O3 with a different Zn amount, and compares the catalytic property of the modified catalysts by introducing other metal elements. The effect of Zn amount, modification on products distribution in PDA cyclization with GL is investigated in details. Simultaneously, the relationship between products distribution and physicochemical property of catalysts is also ascertained according to characterization on acid–base, adsorption capacity and hydrogen spillover over catalysts surface. According to these results, a reasonable cyclization pathway of GL and PDA is proposed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts with a different Zn amount were prepared via the impregnation method. Typically, the dried γ-Al2O3 (0.38–0.83mm, S BET =230.7m2 g−1) particles were impregnated with the desired quantity of aqueous solution containing a different amount of Zn(NO3)2 for 2h at room temperature. They were then dried overnight at 80°C in an oven and calcined at 550°C for 6h in air. The obtained ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts were denoted Z x A, where x represented the introduced weight percent of metallic Zn relative to support Al2O3. The modification of Z x A catalyst by Ce, Mn, Zr, Mo and Ca was carried out according to the same process, the molar ratio of the modified metal element to Zn was 1:2. 2.2 Catalysts characterization XRD patterns of catalysts were recorded on a DX-2700 powder diffractometer (Dandong, China) operated at 30kV and 20mA, using Cu Kα radiation (λ =0.15406nm). The BET specific surface areas (S BET) of samples were measured by the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms at −196°C using an SSA-4200 micromeritics instrument (Builder Co., Beijing). SEM images of typical catalysts were obtained on a Hitachi scanning electron microscope (model S-4800). The surface acidity and alkalinity of catalysts were tested by NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD on a TP-5080 adsorption instrument (Tianjing, China), respectively. The typical procedure was as follows: 0.2g samples (0.38–0.83mm) were loaded and pretreated with N2 at 400°C for 1h to remove the adsorbed water. The adsorption of NH3 (or CO2) and the removal of physically-adsorbed NH3 (or CO2) on catalysts surface using Ar as carrier gas were carried out at room temperature. The desorption of chemically-adsorbed NH3 (or CO2) was carried out by heating from 30 to 850°C (heating rate of 10°Cmin−1) in a 30mlmin−1 of Ar gas. The desorbed NH3 (or CO2) amount per gram catalyst, which was detected by the thermal conductivity detector (TCD), represented the total acidity or total alkalinity. The reducibility or hydrogen spillover of catalyst was investigated by H2-TPR on the same instrument as TPD procedure: 0.2g samples were loaded in a quartz adsorption tube (i.d. 6mm) and pretreated with N2 at 300°C for 1h to remove the adsorbed water. After cooling, the samples were heated by a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 from room temperature to 900°C in a 30mlmin−1 of 5% H2–N2 mixture gas. The produced water was adsorbed by anhydrous CaCl2, the H2 consumption or spilled-over hydrogen was also detected by TCD. 2.3 Catalytic test GL catalytic cyclization with PDA was carried out in a fixed-bed quartz tubular reactor (Ф in =2cm) under atmospheric pressure. The typical procedure was described as follows: 2g catalysts particles (apparent volume 3ml) were sandwiched between quartz wool layers in the reactor and activated in a flow of dry air at 450°C for 3h prior to catalytic test. The catalysts were then flushed with 30mlmin−1 of dry N2 and cooled to 380°C. The aqueous liquid reactants with a molar composition of 1 GL:1 PDA:8.84 water were fed into the catalysts bed by a PDB-FT-2505 syringe feed pump (Jing-Wei Good Friends Co., China) at a rate of 4mlh−1. The liquid products collected in an ice-cooled condenser were analyzed by a GC-2000 gas chromatograph (Chuanyi Analyzer Co., China) equipped a SUPELCOWAX ™ 10 (30m×0.25mm×0.25 um, Supelco, USA) capillary column and a flame ionization detector. The residual reactants concluding GL and PDA, and the produced pyrazinyl compounds were ascertained according to the GC retention time of the corresponding standard reagents (Adamas Reagent Co., Ltd.), their amounts were calculated according to the area of their GC peaks along with the corresponding correction factors. The GC analysis result of typical reaction mixture is shown in Fig. 1S of Supplementary Material. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Effect of Zn amount XRD results of ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts (Fig. 1 ) indicate that the support exists in the form of γ-Al2O3 phase (Pdf No. 1-1308) [19], the introduced Zn species are mainly converted to ZnO phase (Pdf No. 5-664). It is also found that the intensities of diffraction peaks at 2θ =31.6° and 36.9° characteristic for (200) and (111) crystal plane of ZnO phase increase with the increasing Zn amount due to the increase of ZnO crystal grain (see Table 1 ). Additionally, an obvious diffraction peak at 2θ =59.8° also comes forth when Zn amount beyond 9.43%. This peak is attributed to the characteristic of spinel phase ZnAl2O4 (Pdf No. 3-1161), which can also exhibit characteristic peaks at 2θ =31.6° and 36.9°. It shows that a part of ZnO interacts with γ-Al2O3 to spinel phase. From Table 1, it is clearly observed that the BET specific surface area and pore volume of Z x A catalysts decrease with an increasing Zn amount, and however their average pore size drastically decreases firstly and then increases in some extent. From pore distribution of samples (Fig. 2S in Supplementary Material), it is observed that the introduced Zn species first occupy the internal surface of pore in support Al2O3 along with the formation of spinel phase (see XRD results), and the redundant ZnO species are mainly dispersed over the catalyst surface and give rise to the formation of some new pores. NH3-TPD results (Fig. 2a) indicate that the support Al2O3 exhibits two obvious strong NH3-desorption peaks at about 100°C and 490°C, respectively. The former is assigned to the weak acidic sites due to the weak interaction between OH groups of alumina and NH3 through H-bond formation [20,21], and the latter is attributed to the strong acidic sites related to Al3+ cations as Lewis type on the surface of Al2O3 [21,22]. Additionally, NH3-desorption peak at 490°C is drastically weakened and even disappears after introducing ZnO species. It shows that the introduced ZnO species are preferentially located on the strong acidic sites. Moreover, the low-temperature NH3-TPD peak shifts to a lower temperature in some extent. From Table 1 and Fig. 3S in Supplementary Material, it can also be found that NH3-uptake increases with the increasing Zn amount when being above 4.78%, indicating that the ZnO species can provide some weak acidic sites. CO2-TPD results (Fig. 2b) show that Al2O3 support only exhibits a strong CO2-desorption peak at about 75°C, which weakens after introducing ZnO species. It is because that this peak is attributed to the physically-adsorbed CO2 on pore surface of support which can be decreased due to the presence of ZnO species (Table 1). However, the introduction of ZnO into Z x A catalysts is discovered to give rise to the appearance of CO2 desorption peaks at about 165°C, 375°C and 609°C, respectively. These peaks are found to shift to a higher temperature and their intensities also increase in some extent with an increasing Zn amount (Table 1 and Fig. 2b). It indicates that the supported ZnO species can provide some basic sites including weak, medium-strong and strong basic sites. It is possibly because that the ZnO species can provide not only weak Lewis acid, but also strong Brønsted base site pairs (Zn2+–O2−) [23–25]. Catalytic test shows that the GL cyclization with PDA over Z x A catalysts surely produces four kinds of main pyrazinyl compounds including 2,6- and 2,5-DMP, 6- and 5-HMP. From Fig. 3, it can be clearly observed that all catalysts exhibit a high conversion toward both GL and PDA (>92%), the yields toward 6-HMP, 2,6- and 2,5-DMP first decrease slowly with the increasing Zn amount and then increase in some extent when Zn amount beyond 14.87%, however 5-HMP yield exhibits a reverse trend with the increasing Zn amount in Z x A catalyst. These results are possibly due to change of acidic–basic sites resulting from ZnO introduction. With a low Zn amount, Z x A can provides more Lewis acidic sites such as Al3+ and Zn2+ centers. These acidic sites easily adsorb the terminal NH2 groups of PDA, and also give rise to the dehydration or dehydroxylation of GL molecules described as Scheme 3a [26–29]. The steric effect makes GL dehydration easily form hydroxyacetone, and dehydroxylation should produce secondary carbocations with a higher stability. Similarly the steric effect makes the activated PDA easily interact with hydroxyacetone and secondary carbocations to form 2,6-DMP and 6-HMP, respectively. Thus, the higher yields toward 2,6-DMP and 6-HMP than those toward 2,5-DMP and 5-HMP (Fig. 4S in Supplementary Material) are obtained over Al2O3 and Z3A catalyst with more acidic sites. Additionally, dehydration occurs more easily than dehydroxylation of GL molecules over acidic sites, therefore yields toward dimethylpyrazines including 2,6- and 2,5-DMP are obtained to be higher than those toward 6- and 5-HMP. Of course, it is also possible that the formation of 2,6- and 2,5-DMP carries out by self-cyclization of PDA molecules through desamination over acidic sites [10,13], and the steric effect also leads to the formation of more 2,6-DMP than 2,5-DMP. With the further increase on Zn amount, 5-HMP yield drastically increases to the highest value when Zn amount being 14.87%, however yield toward 6-HMP has no increase. It is possibly because that the introduced ZnO species provide the weak Lewis acid-strong Brønsted base site pairs. The dehydrogenation of GL molecules to dihydroxypropanal or dihydroxyacetone easily occurs over basic sites [23,30,31]. Due to the steric effect, the interaction of GL molecules and basic sites will produce more dihydroxypropanal than dihydroxyacetone. Similarly, the steric effect leads to the difficult interaction of carbonyl group in dihydroxypropanal with the adsorbed terminal NH2 group in PDA, resulting in the production of more 5-HMP than 6-HMP. Although the formation of 6-HMP is much easier than that of 5-HMP through interaction of dihydroxyacetone with the activated PDA, the produced dihydroxyacetone is much less. Therefore, the more basic sites favor the formation of 5-HMP according to Scheme 3b. From Fig. 3 , it can also be found that the yield toward 5-HMP decreases, and however 2,6-DMP yield rapidly increases with the increasing Zn amount when beyond 14.87%. It seems contradictory to the reaction mechanism described as Scheme 3b. In fact, the presence of more strong basic sites from Zn2+–O2− pairs and the formation of bigger ZnO crystal grains (Table 1) leads to the difficulty on adsorption of terminal NH2 group in PDA. The carbonyl group in the formed dihydroxypropanal easily attacks the terminal NH2 group of PDA, resulting in the formation of more 6-HMP than 5-HMP. However, it is found that the yield toward 6-HMP has no obvious increase and more 2,6-DMP has been produced. From H2-TPD results (Fig. 5S in Supporting Material), the increase on Zn amount leads to the strong adsorption of H2 molecule on catalysts, which is possibly due to the “p-type” semiconductor behavior of ZnO induced by the heterolytic split (H δ+–H δ−) of H2 [24,32–34]. It indicates that the Z x A catalyst exhibit an excellent potential on activating H2 molecules. Moreover, H2 production will occur during the GL cyclization with PDA to form pyrazinyl compounds, indicating that the present reaction system is a “self-supplying system for active hydrogen” [35]. Therefore, it is proposed that the rapid increase on 2,6-DMP yield and the weak increase on 2,5-DMP yield are due to the hydrodehydration of the formed 6-HMP with the activated H2 when Zn amount beyond 14.87%. 3.2 Effect of modification From Table 2 , it is clearly observed that the introduction of metal elements except Zr increases 6-HMP yield and decreases 5-HMP yield as the order of Ce<Ca<Mn<Mo. Zr–Z15A exhibits a higher 5-HMP yield and a lower 6-HMP yield than Z15A. It is because that Zr exhibits a similar characteristic to Zn, can also provide Zr4+–O2− Lewis acid-Brønsted base pairs, the formation of basic sites improves the dehydrogenation of GL to dihydroxypropanal which favors the production of 5-HMP (Scheme 3b). From SEM images of typical catalysts (Fig. 4 ), it can be easily observed that the presence of Ce, Mn and Mo leads to the high dispersion of ZnO species on surface of catalyst resulting in the formation of small ZnO crystal grain (XRD results in Table 2). Meanwhile these introduced species can also occupy the basic sites and produce a little amount of acidic sites, which is helpful to the formation of 2,6-DMP described as Scheme 3a. Although CaO can provide the basic sites, it is also able to interact with Lewis acidic sites over the surface of Z15A catalyst. It is disadvantageous to the activation of terminal NH2 groups in PDA, which will result in the decrease on PDA conversion and make the formation of 5-HMP and 6-HMP more difficult. Reaction conditions: 2g catalysts, 30mlmin−1 N2 as carrier gas, reaction temperature 380°C, feed rate of liquid reactants (1 GL:1 PDA:8.84 water) 4mlh−1. DMPs includes 2,6-DMP and 2,5-DMP, HMPs includes 6-HMP and 5-HMP, 2,6-pys includes 6-HMP and 2,6-DMP, 2,5-pys includes 5-HMP and 2,5-DMP. From Fig. 5 , the total yield of four target products is decreased by the introduction of Ca, Mn and Mo. It is probably due to the decrease of acidic sites and increase of basic sites, according to NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD results (Fig. 6S in Supplementary Material). However, total selectivity of 6-position substituted 2-methylpyrazines (6-HMP and 2,6-DMP) over Z15A catalysts is obviously increased by the introduction of Ca, Mn and Mo. It seems contrary to the result that the presence of basic sites favors the formation of 5-HMP according to the pathway described as Scheme 3b. In order to investigate this point, H2-TPR is introduced in the present work. H2-TPR results (Fig. 6 ) indicate that all catalysts don’t give a strong reduction peak, however Z15A catalysts modified by Ce, Ca, Mn and Mo give a strong negative peak at about 490°C. The appearance of this negative peak shows that these introduced species possibly result in the spillover phenomenon of hydrogen over surface oxygen anions and oxygen vacancies of catalysts provided by the corresponding oxides [24,36–38]. As reported, the oxides of surface Ce, Mn and Mo should exhibit TPR peak near 500°C [39,40], 470°C [41,42] and above 650°C [43] respectively. However, it is found that only Mo–Z15A gives a weak H2 consumption peak at about 690°C due to the reduction of MoO x , and no obvious H2 consumption peaks for both Ce–Z15A and Mn–Z15A emerges at corresponding temperature, which is possibly because of strong overlap with hydrogen spillover peaks. From Fig. 6, it can be observed that the intensity of hydrogen spillover peak increases as the order of Ce–Z15A<Ca–Z15A<Mn–Z15A<Mo–Z15A, which just accords with the increase order of total selectivity toward 6-position substituted 2-methylpyrazines (Fig. 5) and 6-HMP yield (Table 2). Therefore, it is deduced that the hydrogen spillover improves the dehydrogenation of GL molecule to more dihydroxypropanal as described in Scheme 3b. However, the decrease of acidic sites and increase of basic sites will lead to the difficult activation of PDA molecules. It results in the easy interaction of carbonyl group in dihydroxypropanal with terminal NH2 groups in PDA to more 6-HMP due to steric effect. However, the decrease on activated PDA leads to the draft decrease on the formation of 5-HMP and 2,5-DMP. In addition, the spilled-over hydrogen as activated reactant favors the hydrodehydration of 6-HMP to 2,6-DMP [35]. 3.3 Catalytic stability Catalyst stabilities of four typical Z15A catalysts are compared in the present work. The results (Fig. 7 ) indicate that all Z15A catalysts give a high and stable GL conversion (above 94%) during a stream-time of 240min. Three catalysts except Ca–Z15A exhibit a stable total yield toward four target products, indicating that these three catalysts show an excellent catalytic stability for the synthesis of pyrazinyl compounds from GL and PDA. In the case of Ca–Z15A, the presence of more basic sites leads to the decrease on the activated PDA molecules and increase on formation of dihydroxypropanal (Scheme 3b), which will inhibit the cyclization to pyrazinyl compounds. At the same time, the direct interaction of dihydroxypropanal and PDA can occur to form some impurities such as amines and imines without N-heteroatomic ring, which have been tested by GC. These impurities possibly polymerize on the acidic sites, which further decreases the activation of PDA molecules. It can be proved by the result that PDA conversion decreases with the stream-time (Fig. 7S in Supplementary Material). From Fig. 7S, it can be also seen that the catalytic activity of spent Ca–Z15A can be recovered in some extent after calcination at 500°C in air flow, indicating that Ca–Z15A exhibit a reusable property in GL cyclization with PDA. 4 Conclusions ZnO species on ZnO-based catalysts can provide weak Lewis acid–strong Brønsted base pairs. In synthesis of pyrazinyl compounds from GL and PDA, the formation of 2,6- and 2,5-DMP can directly take place over acidic sites through the GL dehydration and further cyclization with PDA, also through the hydrodehydration of 6- and 5-HMP, respectively. However, the formation of 6- and 5- HMP mainly occurs through the interaction of the activated PDA molecules on acidic sites with dihydroxypropanal or dihydroxyacetone from GL dehydrogenation on basic sites. coredata.dc:description: ZnO-based catalysts on Al2O3 as support are prepared and modified with different metal elements through impregnation, and first applied in synthesis of pyrazinyl compounds from glycerol and 1,2-propanediamine (PDA) in the present work. The results indicate that the produced pyrazinyl compounds mainly include 6-hydroxymethyl-2-methylpyrazine (6-HMP), 5-hydroxymethyl-2-methylpyrazine (5-HMP), 2,6-dimethylpyrazine (2,6-DMP) and 2,5-dimethylpyrazine (2,5-DMP). Characterization results show that ZnO species in catalysts provide acid–base pairs (Zn2+–O2−), catalysts modified by Ce, Ca, Mn and Mo exhibit spillover phenomenon of hydrogen. According to the effect of Zn amount and modification on the physicochemical and catalytic property of ZnO-based catalysts, the cyclization pathway of glycerol with PDA is proposed. The formation of 2,6- and 2,5-DMP is thought to directly take place over acid sites through glycerol dehydration and further cyclization with the activated PDA, also through hydrodehydration of 6- and 5-HMP, respectively. 6- and 5-HMP are mainly produced by the interaction of activated PDA molecules on acidic sites with dihydroxypropanal or dihydroxyacetone from glycerol dehydrogenation on basic sites.
coredata.dc:title: Reaction pathway in vapor-phase synthesis of pyrazinyl compounds from glycerol and 1,2-propanediamine over ZnO-based catalysts
